skill.name: uniprot-database
skill.description: Direct REST API access to UniProt. Protein searches, FASTA retrieval, ID mapping, Swiss-Prot/TrEMBL. For Python workflows with multiple databases, prefer bioservices (unified interface to 40+ services). Use this for direct HTTP/REST work or UniProt-specific control.
skill.summary: Access UniProt protein database for protein searches, sequence retrieval, and ID mapping via REST API
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate scientific skill providing access to UniProt, the trusted public protein database. All 582 static findings are false positives. The scanner misinterpreted markdown code blocks as shell commands and flagged standard HTTP requests to rest.uniprot.org as network activity. No malicious patterns, data exfiltration, or security threats were found.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: These are markdown code block delimiters (```bash, ```python) in documentation files, not actual command execution. The backtick character is standard markdown syntax for inline code and code blocks. No subprocess, os.system, or eval calls exist in the codebase.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: network: Python HTTP libraries, Fetch API calls, Hardcoded URLs (87 locations)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: All network requests target https://rest.uniprot.org, the official UniProt REST API. The codebase uses the standard requests library for legitimate protein database queries. No credential exfiltration, data leaks, or connections to suspicious endpoints were found.

File writes in api_examples.md save protein sequences in FASTA format. This is standard bioinformatics practice for storing sequence data. No sensitive file operations or path traversal vulnerabilities exist.

The scanner flagged pattern matches that do not correspond to actual cryptographic functions. The codebase contains no md5, sha1, or other weak hashing algorithms. This appears to be a pattern-matching false positive.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: blocker: System reconnaissance, Network reconnaissance (6 locations)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: References to taxonomy_id:9606 are NCBI taxonomy identifiers for organisms, not system enumeration. URLs to uniprot.org documentation are legitimate API references. No port scanning, service detection, or reconnaissance code exists.

content.user_title: Query UniProt protein database via REST API
content.value_statement: Search protein databases, retrieve sequences, and map identifiers across biological databases. This skill provides direct access to UniProt, the comprehensive protein sequence and functional information resource.
actual_capabilities: Search proteins by name, gene, accession, or organism using UniProt query syntax
Retrieve protein sequences in FASTA, JSON, TSV, XML, or other formats
Map protein identifiers between UniProt and external databases like PDB, RefSeq, Ensembl
Access Swiss-Prot reviewed entries and TrEMBL unreviewed entries separately
Stream large result sets for batch protein downloads
Build complex queries with field-specific search syntax and boolean operators
limitations: Does not provide graphical interface; operates through API calls only
Rate limits apply to large batch operations; proper delays required
Results from ID mapping jobs are stored for 7 days maximum

use_cases.title: Retrieve protein sequences
use_cases.description: Look up protein sequences by gene name or accession number for downstream analysis

use_cases.title: Map database identifiers
use_cases.description: Convert protein identifiers between UniProt, PDB, RefSeq, and Ensembl formats

use_cases.title: Explore protein annotations
use_cases.description: Access GO terms, functional descriptions, and domain information for teaching

prompt_templates.title: Basic protein search
prompt_templates.prompt: Find human insulin proteins in UniProt and return their accessions and sequences in FASTA format

prompt_templates.title: Gene-specific query
prompt_templates.prompt: Search for reviewed human BRCA1 proteins and show gene names, organism, and length

prompt_templates.title: ID mapping
prompt_templates.prompt: Map these UniProt accessions P01308 and P04637 to their corresponding PDB entries

prompt_templates.title: Complex query
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all reviewed human membrane proteins with kinase activity that have PDB structures

output: â€¢ P69905 - Hemoglobin subunit alpha (HBA1) - 142 aa
â€¢ P68871 - Hemoglobin subunit beta (HBB) - 147 aa
â€¢ P02100 - Hemoglobin subunit epsilon (HBE1) - 147 aa

best_practices: Use reviewed:true in queries to get high-quality Swiss-Prot entries
Request only needed fields to reduce bandwidth and improve speed
Implement rate limiting when processing large batches of accessions
anti_patterns: Do not make concurrent requests without rate limiting
Do not ignore API errors; check response status codes
Do not use outdated accession numbers without verification

faq.question: What is UniProt?
faq.answer: UniProt is the central repository for protein sequence and functional information, combining Swiss-Prot manually curated and TrEMBL automatically annotated entries.

faq.question: How do I get protein sequences?
faq.answer: Use the get_protein function with format='fasta' to retrieve sequences. Example: get_protein('P69905', format='fasta')

faq.question: What databases can I map IDs to?
faq.answer: Supported databases include PDB, RefSeq, Ensembl, GeneID, KEGG, GO, and over 150 others. See the id_mapping_databases.md reference file.

faq.question: What formats are supported?
faq.answer: UniProt API supports JSON, TSV, XML, FASTA, TXT, RDF, Excel, and GFF formats depending on the endpoint.

faq.question: How many proteins can I retrieve at once?
faq.answer: Search queries return up to 500 results per request. For larger datasets, use pagination or the streaming endpoint.

faq.question: What is the difference between Swiss-Prot and TrEMBL?
faq.answer: Swiss-Prot entries are manually reviewed and curated. TrEMBL entries are computationally predicted and unreviewed. Use reviewed:true to filter.
